critique: The document is an executive order regarding the administration of the Foreign Aid Act of 1947. It primarily focuses on delegating authority to the Secretary of State and outlining procedures for inter-agency cooperation. There is a slight expansion of executive power as it centralizes the administration of the Act under the Secretary of State, who is acting on behalf of the President. The document promotes federal control by transferring funds to the Department of State. It has a moderate approach to economic regulation as it involves government in foreign aid. The document is neutral on social issues.
